body_html:
What happened: I created a new season 2016 in the orga/seasons form, with applications dates in Aug 2015. That makes that the link to Apply Now appears in the menu. That's cool. But when I click the link, I got an error message : Applications 2015 are closed.

The current season is always looked up in the year, assuming we won't run two SoCs per year. Creating a 2016 season will still return the 2015 season for Season.current (unless you modify your Rails machine's time to next year).

Warping oneself into a different phase / state of the season requires modifying the various datetime values for the current season.

Changing the season would require an easy way to pick the phase you as a developer would like to see yourself in and set all datetime values appropriately.

That is also only for development, isn't it? Could that be solved with adding a season seed?

I'm against putting that into the seeds.rb. The application will still run w/o users, job offers, and what have you, but it will outright crash without a season. Auto-creating a season is simple enough so I'd like to keep it that way.

body:
> What happened: I created a new season 2016 in the orga/seasons form, with applications dates in Aug 2015. That makes that the link to Apply Now appears in the menu. That's cool. But when I click the link, I got an error message : Applications 2015 are closed.

The _current_ season is always looked up in the year, assuming we won't run two SoCs per year. Creating a 2016 season will still return the 2015 season for `Season.current` (unless you modify your Rails machine's time to next year).

Warping oneself into a different phase / state of the season requires modifying the various datetime values for the _current_ season.

Changing the season would require an easy way to pick the phase you as a developer would like to see yourself in and set all datetime values appropriately.

> That is also only for development, isn't it? Could that be solved with adding a season seed?

I'm against putting that into the seeds.rb. The application will still run w/o users, job offers, and what have you, but it will outright crash without a season. Auto-creating a season is simple enough so I'd like to keep it that way.
